title: Migrant Surge at U.S. Border Prompts White House Talks With Mexico, Guatemala
summary: Biden administration officials set to visit both countries this week as critics call for more actions to stem influx. Senior White House officials are visiting Mexico and Guatemala this week in a bid to curtail a surge of migrants at the U.S. southern border that is raising pressure for the Biden administration to take more aggressive measures.

title: Intel CEO Presses Turnaround Effort With $20 Billion Investment Plan
summary: Chip maker to boost its reliance on outsourcing and renew its efforts to supply semiconductors to others. Intel Corp.'s chief executive is fast-tracking efforts to revive the semiconductor giant with a broad plan that mixes increased outsourcing with a commitment to spend $20 billion on new factories that could help address a chip shortage.

title: TuSimple IPO Filing Shows Self-Driving Trucks Still a Money-Loser
summary: U.S. regulators earlier this month notified the startup it is probing a large Chinese investment. Self-driving company TuSimple Inc. unveiled paperwork for its initial public offering Tuesday showing it has lost more than $300 million over the past three years in the race to be the first to launch fully autonomous long-haul trucks.

title: Biden Pushes Tighter Gun Control After Shooting in Colorado
summary: Gun issue fans the debate over changing Senate rules to end decades of partisan stalemate. WASHINGTON-President Biden called for tightening gun laws after a deadly shooting at a supermarket in Colorado, reviving debate on Capitol Hill and increasing pressure on Democrats as they weigh trying to change Senate rules to more easily pass their priorities.

summary: Plans to boost production and start foundry business come as shortage has made chip manufacturing hot. Intel Corp. is clearly trying to have it all. Recent circumstances just might allow the chip-making giant to get away with it.

title: U.S. Health Officials Raise Concerns Over AstraZeneca Data

title: Before the Shooting
summary: Who is Ahmad Al Aliwi Alissa?. There's a contemporary political compulsion to immediately inject a horrific shooting into ongoing debates about types of weapons and the terms for acquiring them. But before legislating a response, lawmakers should spend some time trying to figure out why Ahmad Al Aliwi Alissa allegedly murdered 10 people on Monday at a Boulder, Colo. supermarket.

title: Amazon Taps Tableau CEO Adam Selipsky to Lead AWS
summary: Early hire for cloud division returns to succeed Andy Jassy, who is set to replace Jeff Bezos when e-commerce giant's founder steps down. title: A Color-Coded Graduation Day

title: Powell Says Stimulus Package Unlikely to Fuel Unwelcome Inflation

title: It Shouldn't Cost the Farm to Fix a Tractor
summary: New ones require software that only authorized dealers are allowed to use.. Today's equipment is chock full of modern technology designed to improve efficiency and increase yields. Those digital features, however, require digital tools to fix-tools that Mr. Hovis can't buy. Modern tractor makers keep their software in house.

title: 'Einstein's Fridge' Review: Heated Arguments
summary: It's arguably the most successful scientiﬁc theory in history, sweeping and precise and revolutionary. Yet virtually no one cares.. During a physics class I took in college, the professor introduced the unit on thermodynamics with a quote from Albert Einstein, who said that it is "the only physical theory of universal content which I am convinced . . . will never be overthrown." I was suitably impressed. Yet within about 10 minutes my enthusiasm flagged. Sure, the field might be eternal, but even Einstein's imprimatur couldn't glamorize the grubby details of heat exchange and energy conservation.

title: 'Fast-Forward: Look Into Your Future' Review: Artificially Expedited Aging
summary: A PBS special prompts tough conversations about getting older and what families can do now to prepare for the inevitable.. A makeover is supposed to make you feel good about yourself. A resigned smile. Unconcealable fear. Through the miracle of cosmetics, prosthetics and a computer blueprint, the 52-year-old has been given the chance to see what she'll look like at 85. To her credit, she doesn't look away.

title: The Staying Inside Guide: Big-Deal Art in Plain-Spoken Venues
summary: During the Great Depression, federal programs funded the creation of thousands of murals in post offices, hospitals and other locations across the country, many of which can now be viewed online. In the ocean of federal relief provided to America's unemployed during and after the Great Depression, paying visual artists to create art was perhaps the most innovative wave then and among the most remembered now. With salaries from the Works Progress Administration and related agencies, thousands of men and women made paintings, sculpture, posters, photographs and, most notably, murals that decorated post offices, schools, hospitals, courthouses and other public buildings across the country.

title: Incredible Shrinking Income Inequality
summary: Its rise is an illusion created by the Census Bureau's failure to account for taxes and welfare.. The refrain is all too familiar: Widening income inequality is a fatal flaw in capitalism and an "existential" threat to democracy. From 1967 to 2017, income inequality in the U.S. spiked 21.4%, and everyone from U.S. senators to the pope says it's an urgent problem. Yet the data upon which claims about income inequality are based are profoundly flawed.

title: Housing Can Weather This
summary: Rising rates, higher material costs and a pulling forward of sales that might otherwise be happening now are all headwinds to the housing market. They may not matter.. The housing market is facing rising interest rates, higher material costs and the simple fact that the flurry of pandemic buying probably pulled some demand forward. But rather than a perfect storm, those things may amount to no more than a passing rain.

title: A Cease-Fire in the Election 2020 Wars
summary: It's past time for both parties to admit their defeats and accept the legitimate results.. I have a proposal for reducing the level of partisan polarization in Congress: Both sides should stand down from electoral controversies that only intensify the country's divisions. House Democrats should abandon their efforts to reverse the outcome of the race in Iowa's Second Congressional District; Republicans should renounce the myth of the stolen 2020 election.

But critics of the nascent market question its longevity, as well as its rationale: Why, they ask, would you spend millions of dollars on art that you can't show off in real life?

title: Fallout from AstraZeneca Data Snafu Could Be Bigger Than It Seems
summary: Company's Covid-19 vaccine controversy puts working relationship with U.S. drug regulators at risk. AstraZeneca 's vaccine data flap is unlikely to cost the company much, at least in the near term. Wall Street should be paying close attention anyway.

title: Are We Training Our Lawyers the Best Way?
summary: Why not focus on an LLB (bachelor of laws) program for undergraduates with appropriate full-tuition scholarships?. Regarding Clifford Winston's "Eliminate the Bar Exam for Lawyers" (op-ed, March 16): The writer seems to conflate the American Bar Association and state licensing authorities in simplistic ways. The Council of the ABA Section of Legal Education and Admissions to the Bar is recognized by the U.S. Education Department as the national accreditor of law schools and serves as an independent arm of the ABA in that capacity. Typically, state supreme courts or their designees regulate who is admitted to the practice of law. The implication by Mr. Winston that the ABA has any authority to dictate state licensing requirements is simply wrong. Working with various stakeholders in legal education, the council will continue to review and improve legal education standards for law schools as it has done for many years.

title: Fed Surrenders Independence, Creates Risk
summary: This isn't a recipe for sound policy under a rule of law and would hinder long-run growth.. Your editorial "Powell Catches the Fiscal Bus" (March 16) correctly warns that, in the current environment, there will be strong "political pressure . . . to keep rates low as far as the eye can see." That is why the Federal Reserve may turn to yield-curve control (YCC). Supporting longer-term federal debt (and thus pegging yields at politically favored rates) is more probable now, especially since the Fed has adopted "flexible average inflation targeting." Policy makers are less concerned with inflation than with higher interest rates on government debt. But YCC isn't without risk: It would encourage further deficit spending, increase the "reach for yield," distort credit markets and increase duration risk. Central bank credibility and independence would suffer as the distance between monetary and fiscal policy shrinks. This isn't a recipe for sound policy under a rule of law and would hinder long-run growth.

title: Postal Service Plan Sees Higher Prices, Slower Mail
summary: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy outlines 10-year plan to plug losses and adapt to world with fewer letters, more e-commerce. More packages, higher prices and a longer window to deliver first-class mail underpin the U.S. Postal Service's plan over the next decade to overhaul the agency's operations and avoid more than $100 billion in projected losses.

summary: Global cold-storage construction market expected to grow to $18.6 billion in 2027 from $7 billion in 2019. A surge in online grocery shopping is intensifying demand for food-storage warehouses, sparking billions of dollars in new real-estate development.

title: Israeli Bond Proposal Threatens to Curb Borrowing by U.S. Real-Estate Firms
summary: Security authority may add new hurdle to a market where U.S. developers have raised billions of dollars. U.S. real-estate companies that have borrowed billions of dollars in the Israeli bond market in recent years are facing new rules proposed by the Israel Securities Authority that would tighten the spigot.

title: Biden's Wealthiest Cabinet Officials: Zients, Lander, Rice Top the List
summary: John Kerry is also expected to be among the wealthiest, but his report is not yet available. Coronavirus response coordinator Jeffrey Zients, science adviser Eric Lander and domestic policy adviser Susan Rice are among President Biden's wealthiest cabinet members and senior aides, disclosures made public over the weekend show.

title: Prince Harry Takes On a New Title: Chief Impact Officer
summary: The Duke of Sussex is going to work for the unicorn employee coaching and mental health startup in his latest foray into business. No longer a working member of the royal family, Prince Harry has a new job: executive at a Silicon Valley startup.

title: Flooding Inundates Australia a Year After Wildfires Raged
summary: Torrential rains prompt evacuation orders for 18,500 people; prime minister expects difficult months ahead. SYDNEY-Unusually heavy rainfall has caused widespread flooding across eastern Australia, triggering evacuation orders for roughly 18,500 people and disrupting supplies of commodities.

title: Airport Retail Shops Pin Hopes on Bump in Travel
summary: Stores and restaurants that survived pandemic collapse see signs of recovery as passenger volumes rebound. Travelers are starting to fly again, offering some relief to beleaguered airport shops and restaurants after the pandemic brought most travel to a standstill.

title: Should Central Banks Tame House Prices? New Zealand Gives It a Try
summary: It is a job the nation's central bank didn't want, having warned that might weaken its ability to affect employment and inflation. WELLINGTON, New Zealand-More than 100 people crowded into an auction of five homes here this month. The first under the hammer-a 60-year-old home, last valued by the government at 840,000 New Zealand dollars in 2018-sold for nearly NZ$1.6 million after 11 minutes of fierce bidding.

title: Europe Despairs as Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout Stalls and Pandemic Grinds On
summary: Resume Subscription. BERLIN-Susan Tabbach feels drained. She has been juggling working and caring full-time for her three small children at home during lockdowns, while worrying about her elderly parents, who aren't vaccinated.

title: Uranium Has That Healthy Glow Again
summary: Uranium's future demand growth is hard to predict, but a couple of years' worth of supply discipline has provided reason for optimism. It has been just over a decade since the Fukushima disaster and the nuclear-fuel industry is cautiously betting prospects for its products have finally recovered.

title: Norway's Central Bank Looks Beyond Covid-19
summary: Oil-rich country's currency is seen strengthening this year as Norges Bank looks to raise interest rates. Norway's central bank has signaled that it plans to take the plunge by making the country the first developed nation to shift from pandemic-era policy and raise interest rates by the end of the year.

title: Pfizer Goes It Alone to Expand Vaccine Business Beyond Covid-19
summary: CEO Albert Bourla says company will use gene-based technology learned by working with Germany's BioNTech to tackle other diseases. Pfizer Inc. aims to expand its vaccine business by becoming a leader in the new gene-based technology behind its successful Covid-19 shots.

title: Musicians Turn to NFTs to Make Up for Lost Revenue
summary: Artists are connecting with fans and generating revenue by selling digital collectibles, even if they are hard to value. After a year with no live performances, musicians are hoping to connect with their fans on the blockchain and make up for lost revenue by selling them nonfungible tokens.

title: Covid-19 Relief Law Gives Companies More Time to Fund Pensions
summary: Single-employer plan sponsors will have 15 years-up from seven now-to cover pension deficits, and flexibility in how money earmarked for 2019 and 2020 pension contributions can be used. Finance chiefs will get more time to cover their companies' pension deficits and more flexibility with the cash they have put into retirement plans as part of the new Covid-19 aid package.

title: London Metal Exchange's Overhaul Meets Resistance
summary: Exchange is likely to pare proposed changes, after key traders say the plans would fray ties with metal producers and consumers. Plans for the biggest overhaul of the London Metal Exchange in over 20 years are likely to be pared back following an outcry by an influential group of traders.

title: Boulder Shooting Leaves 10 Dead, Including Police Officer
summary: Law enforcement had reported an active shooter at a Colorado King Soopers store Monday afternoon. A gunman killed 10 people, including a police officer, Monday afternoon at a supermarket in Boulder, Colo., authorities said.

title: Fire at Giant Auto-Chip Plant Fuels Supply Concerns
summary: Shares of Toyota, Nissan and Honda fell Monday. TOKYO-A fire at a factory of one of the world's leading auto chip makers has added to the troubles of car makers that already have slashed production because of a semiconductor shortage.

title: Regeneron Covid-19 Antibody Drug Reduced Risk of Hospitalization, Death by 70% in Late-Stage Trial
summary: The drug was effective at a higher dose already in use and a lower dose, which the company said it would seek permission to start selling. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc. said its antibody drug reduced the risk of Covid-19 hospitalization or death by about 70% in a large clinical trial, the most definitive evidence yet that the medicine can aid recovery early in the course of disease.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Americans Drove Fewer Miles in 2020. Pedestrians Weren't Safer.
summary: Number of pedestrians killed in motor-vehicle crashes rose slightly in first half of 2020, despite 16.5% drop in miles driven. A big drop-off in driving early in the coronavirus pandemic didn't lead to a reduction in U.S. pedestrian deaths, a nonprofit safety group said, citing speeding as a likely factor and saying the finding is another sign of heightened roadway dangers in the Covid-19 era.

title: White House Teams With Groups on Vaccine-Hesitancy Campaign to Sway Conservatives
summary: Christian Broadcasting Network, Nascar and the American Farm Bureau work to deliver message to people the Biden administration believes it can't reach. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is enlisting the help of groups including the Christian Broadcasting Network Inc. and Nascar to encourage more people to get the Covid-19 vaccine, particularly members of communities that have been the most skeptical.

title: Pro-Trump Lawyer Sidney Powell Seeks to Dismiss Defamation Suit
summary: Dominion Voting Systems filed a $1.3 billion defamation suit against Ms. Powell in January. Pro-Trump attorney Sidney Powell asked a federal court to dismiss a roughly $1.3 billion defamation suit filed against her by Dominion Voting Systems, arguing that her claims the company's voting machines rigged the election for Joe Biden represented her opinion, not statements of fact.

title: New Acting Chief Named for Brooklyn Federal Prosecutors
summary: Mark Lesko takes over U.S. attorney's office in Eastern District of New York, which is investigating Cuomo administration's nursing-home response. The federal prosecutors investigating New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's handling of Covid-19 in nursing homes have a new acting U.S. attorney overseeing that probe and other matters.

title: Biden Administration Officials Put Together $3 Trillion Economic Plan
summary: President is expected to be briefed on the details of the multipart package this week. WASHINGTON-Administration officials are crafting a plan for a multipart infrastructure and economic package that could cost as much as $3 trillion and fulfill key elements of President Biden's campaign agenda, according to people involved in the discussions.

title: Eric Greitens Enters Missouri Senate Race
summary: Greitens resigned as governor in 2018 amid preparations to impeach him following allegations of sexual misconduct. Missouri's former Gov. Eric Greitens, who resigned in 2018 amid legal troubles and a sex scandal, said on Fox News on Monday that he is running for a Senate seat to be left open by Republican Sen. Roy Blunt.

title: Fox Corp. Taps Former U.S. Attorney for Nevada as Compliance Chief
summary: Nicholas Trutanich served as the top prosecutor in Nevada under former President Donald Trump. Fox Corp. said Nicholas Trutanich, a former U.S. attorney for Nevada, would become the company's new chief ethics and compliance officer.

title: Oil Company Leaders Support Carbon Pricing Plan
summary: White House environmental officials host videoconference meeting with executives from 10 of the industry's biggest companies. WASHINGTON-Top oil company executives, in a meeting with White House officials Monday, expressed support for putting a price on carbon emissions as a means to address greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change.
